G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A..proposition: The amount of damages sought is within the jurisdictional limits of the Massachusetts District Court. See G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2, 8..proposition: Venue is therefore proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2, 8.

*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person who owns, keeps, or controls a dog owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to control the animal and to prevent it from causing foreseeable harm to others lawfully on or near the premises.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..support_reasoning: The case is expressly decided on premises liability, not on duties arising from ownership, keeping, or control of a dog. The court emphasizes that defendant was not the owner or keeper, applies general common-law rules for ‘animals ordinarily harmless,’ and concludes there is no negligence absent knowledge or reason to know of dangerous propensities. It therefore does not establish a general Massachusetts rule that any person who owns, keeps, or controls a dog must exercise reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to others on or near the premises; instead, it limits liability to situations involving notice of dangerous propensities or special circumstances.
*Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co.*, 283 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Apart from statute even an owner or keeper of a dog, as our cases recognize, is not liable for bodily injuries inflicted by it in the absence of proof that he knew, or at least should have known, its dangerous propensities … and in the absence of proof of some fault of such owner or keeper. … Where, as in the present case, no statute intervenes, the liability for bodily injuries caused by dogs falls within the general principles governing liability for injuries caused by animals ordinarily harmless.”

*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person who owns, keeps, or controls a dog owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to control the animal and to prevent it from causing foreseeable harm to others lawfully on or near the premises.
*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns product liability, breach of warranty, and Chapter 93A liability arising from an industrial printing press accident. It does not involve dogs, animal ownership, or any duty to control animals on or near premises. Because the case never addresses the existence or scope of a dog owner’s duty, it cannot be authority for the proposition stated.
*Maillet v. ATF-Davidson Co.*, 407 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The opinion is entirely about negligence, breach of warranty, and G. L. c. 93A liability relating to a printing press accident; there is no discussion whatsoever of animals, dogs, or premises liability concerning animal control.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff the duty imposed by Massachusetts common law to act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion assumes for purposes of analysis that a negligence duty may exist but explicitly declines to decide whether the defendant owed any duty of care because the case is resolved on the element of causation. It does not articulate, expand, or affirm a Massachusetts common-law duty that the defendant act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances. Thus, it is not authority for the specific duty proposition cited.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt: "Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment."

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff the duty imposed by Massachusetts common law to act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes, as a matter of Massachusetts common law, that a homeowner in the defendant’s position owed a “duty of reasonable care” and frames that duty in terms of what a reasonable person would do under the circumstances. The court reverses summary judgment precisely because it finds such a general negligence duty exists, leaving it to the jury to decide whether the defendant met the standard of reasonable care. This aligns directly with the proposition that the defendant owed the plaintiff a common-law duty to act as a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (200.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care… We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’… In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access… has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured.”

*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.raw_text: *Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.*, 408 Mass. 355, 359–60 (1990)
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, violation of a safety statute, ordinance, or regulation is evidence of negligence as to the harm the statute was designed to prevent.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the effect of violating a safety statute (here, G.L. c. 138, § 69) on civil negligence liability. It reiterates the long-standing Massachusetts rule that statutory violation is not negligence per se but is only ‘some evidence’ of negligence as to the consequences the statute was intended to prevent, which matches the proposition stated. The court also cites prior cases applying this ‘some evidence’ standard in the tavern-liability context.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

*MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, violation of a safety statute, ordinance, or regulation is evidence of negligence as to the harm the statute was designed to prevent.
*MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp..support_reasoning: The court expressly discusses the evidentiary effect of regulatory violations, stating that violation of FDA requirements is evidence, but not conclusive evidence, of negligence. That is the Massachusetts rule on safety statutes and regulations generally, and the court cites prior Massachusetts authority (Deignan v. Lubarsky) for that proposition. Thus the opinion directly supports the claimed proposition about violations being evidence of negligence, not negligence per se, and only as to harms within the statute’s protective scope.
*MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp..relevant_excerpt: “Thus, compliance with FDA requirements, though admissible to demonstrate lack of negligence, is not conclusive on this issue, just as violation of FDA requirements is evidence, but not conclusive evidence, of negligence. See Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661, 664 (1945).”

*Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.raw_text: *Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 403 Mass. 119, 124 (1988)
*Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, violation of a safety statute, ordinance, or regulation is evidence of negligence as to the harm the statute was designed to prevent.
*Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.case_name: Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.support_reasoning: The opinion in Anzalone does not discuss negligence standards, safety statutes, ordinances, or regulations, nor does it address the evidentiary effect of violating such enactments. The case concerns Chapter 93A applicability, workers’ compensation exclusivity, and intentional torts between co-employees within an employment relationship. Accordingly, it does not establish or affirm the rule that violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence as to the harm the statute was designed to prevent.
*Anzalone v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.relevant_excerpt: Thus, these claims are covered exclusively by c. 152. See Albanese’s Case, 378 Mass. 14 (1979) (claim for emotional distress covered by G. L. c. 152); Fitzgibbons’s Case, 374 Mass. 633 (1978) (same). The judge correctly dismissed Anzalone’s count against O’Loughlin.

*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.raw_text: *Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 Mass. 790, 794–95 (1987)
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent actor is liable for harms that are the natural and probable consequence of the negligence, including injuries resulting from a plaintiff’s reasonable efforts to avoid perceived danger created by the defendant.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses proximate cause and superseding/intervening causes, but it does not address the specific principle that a negligent actor is liable for injuries resulting from a plaintiff’s reasonable efforts to avoid perceived danger created by the defendant. The court’s causation analysis focuses on whether the employer’s conduct was a superseding cause and on foreseeability of product use, not on rescue or avoidance-type conduct by the plaintiff. The cited language about ‘natural and probable connection’ concerns intervening causes generally, not the specific ‘efforts to avoid danger’ rule described in the proposition.
*Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG*, 399 M.relevant_excerpt: “In McDonald v. Snelling, 14 Allen 290, 296 (1867), we stated that ‘[t]he test is to be found, not in the number of intervening events or agents, but in their character, and in the natural and probable connection between the wrong done and the injurious consequence.’ See Jesionek, supra at 105; Lane, supra at 140.”

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a negligent actor is liable for harms that are the natural and probable consequence of the negligence, including injuries resulting from a plaintiff’s reasonable efforts to avoid perceived danger created by the defendant.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The case squarely addresses foreseeability and proximate cause, holding that a negligent actor can be liable for harm caused by a foreseeable intervening third party (the intoxicated seaman). However, it does not discuss or apply any rule about liability for injuries arising from a plaintiff’s reasonable efforts to avoid a perceived danger created by the defendant; the plaintiff here was injured by the forklift itself, not while reacting to avoid it. Thus the opinion supports the general foreseeability/proximate cause aspect but not the specific “efforts to avoid danger” component of the proposition.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated, not in the number of subsequent events and agencies which might arise.’”

*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.raw_text: *Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Builders, Inc.*, 441 Mass. 131, 142–43 (2004)
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for all harms proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.case_name: Shantigar Foundation v. Bear Mountain Builders
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns comparative negligence, allocation of fault among multiple tortfeasors, and evidentiary issues about a duty to install sprinklers in a property-damage fire case. It does not address the categories of recoverable tort damages in Massachusetts, such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, emotional distress, or loss of enjoyment of life. The cited pages explain how negligence is apportioned and do not set out or apply any rule about what elements of damages a plaintiff may recover, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
*Shantigar Found. v. Bear Mountain Build.relevant_excerpt: The comparative negligence statute provides, in relevant part: “Contributory negligence shall not bar recovery in any action ... to recover damages for negligence ... if such negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the person or persons against whom recovery is sought, but any damages allowed shall be diminished in proportion to the amount of negligence attributable to the person for whose injury, damage or death recovery is made. In determining by what amount the plaintiff’s damages shall be diminished in such a case, the negligence of each plaintiff shall be compared to the total negligence of all persons against whom recovery is sought.”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for all harms proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not set out a general catalogue of recoverable tort damages such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life. Instead, it addresses the narrower question of when emotional distress is compensable in negligence and holds that Massachusetts does not allow recovery for purely emotional distress absent physical harm. While it assumes that prenatal injuries, if proved, are generally compensable, it never articulates the broad remedial principle claimed in the proposition, so this case is not appropriate authority for that statement.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "We remain convinced that the possibilities of fictitious claims and recovery of damages based on speculation should not bar the plaintiffs' action for injuries that can be demonstrated to exist by medical evidence, and for all harm to the plaintiffs that is naturally and reasonably related to those injuries. The certified question assumes that the plaintiffs can prove negligence and causation. 'If the tortious conduct and the legal causation of the harm can be satisfactorily established, there may be recovery for any injury occurring at any time after conception.'"

Plaintiff also seeks prejudgment interes.raw_text: Plaintiff also seeks prejudgment interest on her damages at the statutory rate from the date of commencement of this action, as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B.
Plaintiff also seeks prejudgment interes.proposition: Plaintiff also seeks prejudgment interest on her damages at the statutory rate from the date of commencement of this action, as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: However, to the extent any negligence is attributed to Plaintiff, her damages should be reduced only in accordance with Massachusetts comparative negligence law.

*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..proposition: However, to the extent any negligence is attributed to Plaintiff, her damages should be reduced only in accordance with Massachusetts comparative negligence law.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses how a plaintiff’s negligence affects recovery in a Massachusetts negligence/products case. It explains that under G.L. c. 231, § 85, a plaintiff’s contributory negligence does not bar recovery unless it exceeds the defendants’ negligence, and otherwise only reduces damages proportionally. That is exactly the principle stated in the proposition that any negligence attributed to the plaintiff should reduce her damages only in accordance with Massachusetts comparative negligence law.
*Colter v. Barber-Greene Co.*, 403 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “In a negligence case, the conduct of the plaintiff which will serve to bar recovery is governed by statute. Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

Pursuant to applicable Massachusetts law.raw_text: Pursuant to applicable Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 218, § 19B and related provisions, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
Pursuant to applicable Massachusetts law.proposition: Pursuant to applicable Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 218, § 19B and related provisions, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
